message.content: This question requires basic knowledge about the properties and behavior of steam. When steam collects on the sides of a bucket, it usually condenses and forms droplets of water. These droplets then pool on the sides of the bucket. Option (A) is incorrect because steam does not melt. Option (B) is incorrect because steam does not fry. Option (D) is unrelated to the behavior of steam.

This question requires basic knowledge about the behavior of steam. When steam comes in contact with a cooler surface, such as the sides of a bucket, it condenses and turns back into water. The water droplets then collect and pool on the sides of the bucket. Option (A) is incorrect because steam does not melt, it condenses into water. Option (B) is unrelated to the behavior of steam. Option (D) is incorrect because steam does not glow.

When steam from a hot bucket of water comes into contact with a cooler surface, such as the sides of the bucket, it condenses and collects as water droplets. This pooling of condensation is the correct answer. Option (A) is incorrect because steam does not melt. Option (B) is incorrect because steam does not fry. Option (D) is incorrect because steam does not glow.

When steam comes into contact with a cooler surface, such as the sides of a bucket, it condenses and forms droplets of water. These droplets then collect and pool on the sides of the bucket. Option (A) is incorrect because melting refers to a solid changing into a liquid, not the behavior of steam. Option (B) is incorrect because frying refers to the cooking process and is not related to the behavior of steam. Option (D) is incorrect because glowing refers to emitting light and is not related to the behavior of steam.

Option (B) is not related to the process of condensation. Option (D) is unrelated to the physical properties of steam and is not applicable in this situation.
